awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I: A Fully Autonomous Prognostic Digital Twin for Smart Manufacturing
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to assist industries reduce their downtime for scheduled, preventative maintenance.  Industries with high-value assets like manufacturing facilities, engines, satellites, reactors, etc., often incur significant expense due to a lack of usable insights into productivity optimization. The forecasting technology and the developments stemming from this project will have general applicability and enable the use of prescriptive prognostics (when and what to repair) in diverse markets. Additionally, the methods developed in the project for training deep learning systems on limited data would have broad application within the machine learning (ML) community. Frequently, projects are limited by access to and availability of data. The methods developed in this project could be applied to small sets of medical data or financial data, as they are entirely defined on time series variables and dynamics. 

This SBIR Phase I project has two main goals. First, to develop a technology that will enable full autonomy in the extraction of meaningful feature sets from raw sensor data. An autonomous feature selection procedure developed in this project will exploit the combination of powerful control-theoretic results with modern ML tools to discover non-obvious linear and nonlinear features. This solution will provide a physics-informed architecture, allowing users to incorporate available physics knowledge with that emerging from the data, configuring a robust, flexible, and autonomous feature extraction mechanism. Second, the team will construct a robust, multi-modal, sensor emulator to address data insufficiency in order to train the ML components. This opportunity is in response to the limited availability of data in manufacturing sector, especially time-series sensor data in operational systems. The sensor emulator will be formed via combinations of modern ML-based generative tools in a manner that exploits their proven effectiveness while being able to work with high-dimensional signals and small training datasets.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
Executive Summary: Industries with high-value physical assets are prone to unnecessary downtime created by preventive maintenance schedules. This leads to the loss of millions of dollars per day. Existing prognostic solutions have failed to effectively identify impending system failures in time, because they cannot generate timely and trustworthy forecasts of critical events that foreshadow system failure. This SBIR Phase I project performed by PointPro Inc. located in Columbus OH concerns prognostic digital twins tasked with the problem of forecasting a complex system's path to failure, e.g., a CNC milling machine. The physics of failure is invariably very complex and for machine learning (ML) models to adequately represent the underlying physics, the number of training data points must keep pace with the complexity of the ML model.  which can be on the order of tens of thousands. However, in niche industrial scenarios like the one considered here, the availability of data is limited; on the order of a few hundred data points, at best. Notwithstanding the popular notion of big-data, there is a stark shortage of ground-truth data when examining a complex system's path to failure. In this project we developed and enhanced "DAGGER": a deep-learning platform that can robustly, efficiently and reliably augment available sensor data to help train complex data-based computational models for smart manufacturing. DAGGER captures specific evolutionary characteristics of system degradation, reliably predicting failure before it happens. This would allow operators to take corrective action in time, ultimately maximizing asset productivity. This project created opportunities to train professionals and interns, resulted in peer-reviewed publications, and helped expand PointPro's scope through technical interchange meetings, site visits, and participation in a U.S. Space Force Technology Development Accelerator Program.

Project's Technological Outcomes (Intellectual Merits): We optimized and tested the Data AuGmentation GEneRative (DAGGER) framework as a deep-learning tool, combining the strengths of two powerful ML frameworks: so-called autoencoders (AEs) and generative adversarial networks (GANs). Through this integration, we augmented available sensor data in a robust and efficient manner to train the data-based computational models for smart manufacturing. The DAGGER framework accomplishes its objectives in a stable manner even if the input data size is small. The project exhaustively corroborated the efficacy of DAGGER by testing it on both benchmark problems and real-world datasets obtained from a CNC milling center.  

Project's Activities, Training and Tangible Outputs (Broader Impacts): The project provided training opportunities for two senior scientists at PointPro Inc. Both personnel had strong academic preparation, one with a Ph.D. in Electrical Engineering and the other in Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering. In addition, the project provided software management training for one full time person. Finally, the project created the opportunity for one Business Major intern during Summer 2024 to help develop the commercialization strategy for PointPro. The project resulted in two conference papers (one focused on DAGGER and the other on Digital Twins), both published at the 15th Annual Conference of the Prognostics and Health Management Society. The DAGGER paper earned a nomination for the best paper award at this technical meeting. A journal version of this paper is under development. 

As part of project activities, PointPro conducted a Technical Interchange Meeting (TIM) on January 30, 2024, which was attended by 16 participants from industry in the manufacturing and predictive analytics sector, students, NSF personnel and collaborators from AFRL. The TIM provided an opportunity for exchange of ideas and collaboration in the area of digital twins for smart manufacturing systems and beyond. 

As part of building our commercial portfolio, PointPro established connection with a leading company in the commercial vehicle industry, which manufactures parts for semi-trucks. Our focus is first with a manufacturing plant in Chillicothe OH, where the plant manager is looking to incorporate using new technology for maintenance. Until now, this plant has been using a reactive maintenance method, manually surveilling its robotic arms used for hypersonic welding. When machinery breaks down, the production line is halted, sometimes for days at a time. We aim to address this problem with a pilot project. 

Finally, with increasing visibility, PointPro was invited to participate in Cohorts 3-5 of the Space Domain Awareness (SDA) TAP LAB (Tools, Applications and Processing LAB) hosted by the Space Systems Command in Colorado Springs, CO. As part of this engagement, PointPro developed predictive analytics solutions for management of USSF space assets, including a sensor tasking algorithm and a reentry prediction service. 

 


Last Modified: 12/16/2024
Modified by: Mrinal Kumar
